metadata.description: EPA Section 608 certification - refrigerant handling, recovery, regulations

questions.question: What law established the regulation of ozone-depleting substances in the United States?

choices.b: Clean Air Act

explanation.short: The Clean Air Act, specifically Section 608, regulates the handling and disposal of ozone-depleting refrigerants.
explanation.detailed: The Clean Air Act was amended in 1990 to address ozone depletion. Section 608 specifically covers refrigerant management, requiring: technician certification; proper recovery equipment; prohibition of venting; record keeping; and leak repair requirements. EPA enforces these regulations with significant penalties for violations.

questions.question: In which layer of the atmosphere is the ozone layer located?

choices.b: Stratosphere

explanation.short: The ozone layer is in the stratosphere, approximately 10-30 miles above Earth's surface.
explanation.detailed: The stratospheric ozone layer absorbs harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. CFCs and HCFCs release chlorine when they reach the stratosphere, which destroys ozone molecules. One chlorine atom can destroy thousands of ozone molecules. This is why these refrigerants are being phased out.

questions.question: What does ODP stand for?

choices.b: Ozone Depletion Potential

explanation.short: ODP (Ozone Depletion Potential) measures a substance's ability to destroy ozone relative to CFC-11 (R-11), which has an ODP of 1.0.
explanation.detailed: ODP is a comparative scale: CFC-11 = 1.0 (reference); CFC-12 = 1.0; HCFC-22 = 0.055 (much lower but not zero); HFCs like R-410A = 0 (no chlorine, no ozone impact). Lower ODP is better for ozone. HCFCs were transitional refrigerants; HFCs have zero ODP but may have high GWP (global warming potential).

questions.question: What does GWP measure?

choices.b: Global Warming Potential - heat trapping ability relative to CO2

explanation.short: GWP (Global Warming Potential) measures how much heat a gas traps in the atmosphere compared to CO2 over a given time period.
explanation.detailed: GWP uses CO2 as the reference (GWP = 1). R-410A has GWP of 2088 - it traps 2088 times more heat than CO2. R-32 has GWP of 675 (lower). AIM Act targets HFCs with high GWP. Future refrigerants will have both low ODP AND low GWP. GWP is typically measured over 100 years.

questions.question: How many types of EPA Section 608 technician certification are there?

choices.b: Three

explanation.short: There are four types: Type I (small appliances), Type II (high-pressure), Type III (low-pressure), and Universal (all types).
explanation.detailed: Type I: Small appliances (under 5 lbs charge) - window AC, refrigerators, PTACs. Type II: High-pressure equipment (most AC/refrigeration using R-22, R-410A, R-404A). Type III: Low-pressure equipment (chillers using R-11, R-123). Universal: Certified for all equipment types. Most technicians need Type II or Universal.

questions.question: What type of equipment does Type II certification cover?

choices.b: High-pressure equipment like AC systems and heat pumps

explanation.short: Type II covers high-pressure equipment including most residential and commercial AC, heat pumps, and medium-temp refrigeration.
explanation.detailed: High-pressure refrigerants have boiling points between -50°C and 10°C at atmospheric pressure. Examples: R-22, R-410A, R-134a, R-404A. Most common HVAC equipment uses these refrigerants. Type II is the most common certification for HVAC technicians. Covers equipment containing more than 5 lbs of refrigerant.

questions.question: Is it legal to intentionally vent refrigerants to the atmosphere?

choices.a: Yes, if the amount is small
choices.b: No, venting is prohibited with limited exceptions

explanation.short: Intentional venting is prohibited under Section 608 with limited exceptions for de minimis releases during service.
explanation.detailed: Venting prohibition applies to CFC, HCFC, and HFC refrigerants. Exceptions: de minimis releases during connection/disconnection; releases from purging (must use recovery equipment); and release of non-exempt substitute refrigerants as allowed. Penalties for venting can be up to $44,539 per day per violation. Nitrogen and CO2 used for leak testing may be released.

questions.question: Before opening a system for service, what must be done with the refrigerant?

choices.a: Nothing if charge is less than 10 lbs
choices.b: Refrigerant must be recovered to required levels

explanation.short: Refrigerant must be recovered to required vacuum levels before opening any system for service or disposal.
explanation.detailed: Recovery requirements apply before making any repair that requires opening the system. Required recovery levels depend on equipment type and date of manufacture. For systems with more than 200 lbs charge manufactured after 1993: recover to 0 psig for high-pressure systems if non-operating. Recovery equipment must be certified to meet EPA standards.

questions.question: For a Type II (high-pressure) system with less than 200 lbs charge using recovery equipment manufactured after Nov 15, 1993, what is the required recovery level?

choices.b: 0 psig

explanation.short: High-pressure systems under 200 lbs must be recovered to 0 psig using post-1993 recovery equipment.
explanation.detailed: Required recovery levels for high-pressure equipment using equipment manufactured after Nov 15, 1993: Less than 200 lbs charge = 0 psig; 200 lbs or more = 0 psig. For older recovery equipment: less than 200 lbs = 0 psig; 200+ lbs = 4 inches Hg vacuum. These levels apply when system will be opened for service or disposal. Lower vacuum = more refrigerant recovered.

questions.question: What certification must recovery equipment meet?

choices.b: AHRI 740 or EPA-approved equivalent

explanation.short: Recovery equipment must be certified to AHRI 740 standard or equivalent, verifying it can achieve required recovery efficiency.
explanation.detailed: AHRI Standard 740 (formerly ARI 740) establishes minimum performance requirements for refrigerant recovery equipment. Equipment must meet efficiency standards for the refrigerant types it will handle. Manufacturers self-certify equipment to the standard. EPA requires use of certified equipment. The standard addresses recovery rate, final recovery vacuum, and other performance criteria.

questions.question: What is the leak repair requirement for commercial refrigeration equipment containing more than 50 lbs of refrigerant?

choices.b: Repair when leak rate exceeds 20%

explanation.short: Commercial refrigeration with >50 lbs charge must have leaks repaired when the annual leak rate exceeds 20%.
explanation.detailed: Leak repair trigger rates for equipment with 50+ lbs charge: Commercial refrigeration = 20% annual leak rate; Industrial process refrigeration = 30%; Comfort cooling = 10% (added by AIM Act). Owners must repair leaks or retire equipment within 30 days of exceeding trigger rate. Records must be kept. Leak rate = (refrigerant added) / (full charge) over rolling 365 days.

questions.question: Under the AIM Act, what is the leak repair threshold for comfort cooling equipment with 50+ lbs of refrigerant?

choices.b: 20% annual leak rate

explanation.short: The AIM Act extended leak repair requirements to comfort cooling, with a 10% threshold for equipment with 50+ lbs charge.
explanation.detailed: Previously, EPA 608 leak repair requirements only covered refrigeration, not comfort cooling (AC). The AIM Act of 2020 extended requirements to HVAC. Systems with 50+ lbs must track refrigerant additions and repair when leak rate exceeds 10% annually. This affects larger commercial and industrial AC systems. Same 30-day repair requirement applies.

questions.question: To what maximum level should recovery cylinders be filled?

choices.b: 80% of capacity at 77°F

explanation.short: Recovery cylinders must not be filled beyond 80% of capacity at 77°F to allow for liquid expansion.
explanation.detailed: Liquid refrigerant expands as temperature increases. If a cylinder is 100% filled with liquid and temperature rises, hydrostatic pressure can rupture the cylinder catastrophically. 80% fill level at 77°F provides safe expansion space. Recovery cylinders must meet DOT standards. Weighing is the most accurate method to verify fill level. Never heat cylinders to increase pressure.

questions.question: What color is a recovery cylinder typically painted?

choices.b: Light blue

explanation.short: Recovery cylinders are gray with a yellow top to distinguish them from virgin refrigerant cylinders.
explanation.detailed: Color coding prevents mixing virgin and recovered refrigerant: Recovery cylinders = gray body, yellow top; Virgin refrigerant = color-coded by type (R-22 = green, R-410A = rose/pink, R-134a = light blue). Recovery cylinders are DOT-approved reusable containers. Never use disposable cylinders for recovery - they're not rated for recharging.

questions.question: What should be done if different refrigerants are accidentally mixed in a recovery cylinder?

choices.b: Send to a reclaimer for proper separation or destruction

explanation.short: Mixed refrigerants must be sent to a certified reclaimer for separation or destruction - they cannot be reused as-is.
explanation.detailed: Mixed refrigerants cannot be reused in systems because the mixture has different properties than either pure refrigerant. Reclaimers have equipment to separate or destroy mixed refrigerants. Avoid mixing by: using dedicated cylinders for each refrigerant type; identifying refrigerant before recovery; properly labeling cylinders. Mixed refrigerant has no value and disposal is costly.

questions.question: What is the difference between recycling and reclaiming refrigerant?

choices.b: Recycling is basic cleaning; reclaiming restores to virgin specifications with testing
choices.c: Reclaiming is done on-site; recycling is off-site
choices.d: Recycling requires certification; reclaiming does not

explanation.short: Recycling is basic field cleaning (oil separation, filtering). Reclaiming restores refrigerant to ARI 700 virgin specifications through certified processing.
explanation.detailed: Recycling: on-site cleaning using recovery/recycling equipment; removes oil, moisture, and particulates; refrigerant can be reused in same owner's equipment. Reclaiming: off-site processing by EPA-certified reclaimer; chemical analysis; restoration to AHRI 700 purity standard; can be sold as virgin equivalent. Only reclaimed refrigerant should be used in equipment owned by others.

questions.question: What standard specifies purity requirements for reclaimed refrigerant?

choices.b: AHRI 700

explanation.short: AHRI 700 specifies purity requirements that reclaimed refrigerant must meet to be equivalent to virgin refrigerant.
explanation.detailed: AHRI Standard 700 (Specifications for Refrigerants) defines purity requirements for new, reclaimed, and repackaged refrigerants. Includes limits on: moisture content; non-condensables; acidity; chloride content; particulates; and other contaminants. Reclaimed refrigerant meeting AHRI 700 can be sold and used like virgin refrigerant. Reclaimers must certify compliance.

questions.question: Who can purchase regulated refrigerants?

choices.b: Only EPA Section 608 or 609 certified technicians

explanation.short: EPA regulations require that CFC, HCFC, and HFC refrigerants be sold only to certified technicians.
explanation.detailed: Sales restriction applies to: CFCs, HCFCs, and (under AIM Act) HFCs in containers over 2 lbs. Sellers must verify technician certification before sale. Exception: small cans for MVACs may be sold to non-technicians if self-sealing. Records of sales must be kept. This prevents unqualified persons from obtaining and potentially venting refrigerants.

questions.question: When was the production of CFC refrigerants banned in the US?

explanation.short: CFC production was banned on January 1, 1996 under the Montreal Protocol and Clean Air Act.
explanation.detailed: CFCs (like R-11, R-12) have high ozone depletion potential. Production and import were banned as of January 1, 1996. Existing CFC equipment can still be serviced using recovered/reclaimed refrigerant. No new CFC equipment can be manufactured. This is why CFC refrigerants are expensive - supply comes only from recovery. HCFCs followed with later phaseout.

questions.question: When was the production and import of R-22 banned?

explanation.short: R-22 (HCFC-22) production and import was banned on January 1, 2020; only recycled/reclaimed R-22 is now available.
explanation.detailed: HCFC phaseout was gradual: new equipment production banned in 2010; virgin refrigerant production/import banned January 1, 2020. Existing R-22 equipment can still be serviced using recovered and reclaimed refrigerant indefinitely. No requirement to retrofit or replace, but R-22 cost has increased significantly. Many owners choose to convert to R-410A systems.

questions.question: What does the AIM Act primarily target?

choices.b: HCFCs

explanation.short: The AIM Act (American Innovation and Manufacturing Act) targets HFC phasedown to reduce global warming potential.
explanation.detailed: AIM Act of 2020 requires 85% phasedown of HFC production and consumption by 2036 (from 2011-2013 baseline). Unlike CFCs/HCFCs (phased out for ozone), HFCs are targeted for climate impact (high GWP). This will affect R-410A (GWP 2088) and other common HFCs. Transition is to lower-GWP alternatives like R-32, R-454B, and R-290.

questions.question: What classification system does ASHRAE 34 use for refrigerant safety?

choices.b: Letter (toxicity) + Number (flammability) like A1, A2L, B2

explanation.short: ASHRAE 34 classifies refrigerants by toxicity (A=lower, B=higher) and flammability (1=none, 2L=lower, 2=moderate, 3=high).
explanation.detailed: ASHRAE 34 safety classification: Letter A = lower toxicity; B = higher toxicity. Number 1 = no flame propagation; 2L = lower flammability (burning velocity <10 cm/s); 2 = flammable; 3 = highly flammable. Examples: R-410A = A1 (safest); R-32 = A2L (mildly flammable); R-290 (propane) = A3 (highly flammable); R-717 (ammonia) = B2L (toxic, mildly flammable).

questions.question: What does A2L classification mean for a refrigerant?

choices.b: Lower toxicity, lower flammability (mildly flammable)

explanation.short: A2L means lower toxicity (A) and lower flammability (2L) - mildly flammable with slow burning velocity.
explanation.detailed: A2L refrigerants include R-32, R-454B, and R-1234yf. 'Lower flammability' means burning velocity under 10 cm/s - they ignite with difficulty and burn slowly. Requires safety precautions but less stringent than A2 or A3. These are the likely replacements for R-410A in HVAC. Training on safe handling of A2L refrigerants is increasingly important.

questions.question: What is R-410A's safety classification?

choices.b: A2L - mildly flammable

explanation.short: R-410A is classified A1 - non-toxic and non-flammable, the safest classification.
explanation.detailed: R-410A (blend of R-32 and R-125) is A1: lower toxicity and no flame propagation under test conditions. This is the safest category and has allowed widespread residential use without special safety requirements. However, R-410A has high GWP (2088) and is being phased down under AIM Act. Replacements may be A2L, requiring additional safety measures.

questions.question: How should R-410A be charged into a system?

choices.b: Liquid only

explanation.short: R-410A must be charged as liquid because it's a zeotropic blend that would fractionate if charged as vapor.
explanation.detailed: R-410A is a near-azeotropic blend of R-32 (50%) and R-125 (50%). If charged as vapor, the more volatile component (R-32) would vaporize first, changing the blend ratio. Liquid charging keeps components in correct proportion. Charge liquid into suction line with system running (throttle flow to prevent slugging) or into liquid line with system off. Use cylinder dip tube or invert cylinder.

questions.question: Compared to R-22, how do R-410A operating pressures compare?

choices.b: R-410A pressures are approximately 50-60% higher

explanation.short: R-410A operates at approximately 50-60% higher pressure than R-22 at the same temperatures.
explanation.detailed: At 100°F, R-22 condenses at about 196 psig; R-410A at about 317 psig. This means: R-410A systems require higher-rated components; R-22 equipment cannot be converted to R-410A; service equipment (manifolds, hoses) must be rated for R-410A pressures; and recovery equipment must handle higher pressures. Always use proper equipment for the refrigerant.

questions.question: What type of oil is typically used with R-410A systems?

choices.b: Alkylbenzene (AB)

explanation.short: R-410A requires POE (polyol ester) oil because HFC refrigerants don't mix with mineral oil.
explanation.detailed: HFC refrigerants (including R-410A) are not miscible with traditional mineral oil. POE oil is required for proper lubrication and oil return. POE is hygroscopic (absorbs moisture) - keep containers sealed, minimize system exposure during service, and evacuate thoroughly before charging. Never mix oil types. Some retrofits may use POE with R-22 as a transitional measure.

questions.question: Why is moisture especially harmful in systems using POE oil?

choices.b: POE is hygroscopic and moisture causes acid formation that damages compressors

explanation.short: POE oil is hygroscopic (attracts moisture) and moisture reacts with POE to form acids that damage compressor windings and bearings.
explanation.detailed: POE absorbs moisture from air much faster than mineral oil. Moisture + POE + heat = acid formation (hydrolysis). Acid attacks motor windings, bearings, and system components. Prevention: keep oil containers sealed; minimize system exposure time during service; use proper evacuation procedures (500 microns or less); use filter driers rated for HFC/POE systems. More critical than with R-22/mineral oil systems.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of evacuating a refrigeration system?

choices.b: Remove air and moisture (non-condensables)

explanation.short: Evacuation removes air (non-condensables) and moisture from the system before charging.
explanation.detailed: Air in a system causes: high head pressure (air doesn't condense); reduced capacity; increased energy use. Moisture causes: ice at metering device; acid formation; copper plating. Evacuation uses vacuum pump to remove air and boil off moisture at low pressure. Deep vacuum (500 microns) ensures moisture is removed. Never use refrigerant to purge - that's venting.

questions.question: What is the recommended evacuation level for proper system dehydration?

choices.b: 500 microns or less

explanation.short: Proper evacuation requires pulling the system to 500 microns or less to ensure complete moisture removal.
explanation.detailed: Vacuum depth is measured in microns (1000 microns = 1 mm Hg = 0.039 inches Hg). At 500 microns, water boils at about 35°F - cold enough to remove moisture at normal ambient temperatures. After pulling to 500 microns, isolate the pump and perform a standing vacuum test. If vacuum rises above 1000 microns in 10 minutes, there's a leak or moisture remains. Triple evacuate if moisture is suspected.

questions.question: What instrument accurately measures deep vacuum for evacuation?

choices.b: Digital micron gauge or thermocouple gauge

explanation.short: A digital micron gauge or thermocouple vacuum gauge is required to measure deep vacuum levels for proper evacuation.
explanation.detailed: Standard compound gauges only read to about 30 inches Hg (25,000+ microns) - not accurate for deep vacuum. Micron gauges read from 0 to 25,000+ microns with accuracy needed to verify proper evacuation. They measure actual vacuum, not just differential from atmosphere. Position at the system (not at pump) for accurate readings. Essential equipment for proper system dehydration.

questions.question: What gas is recommended for pressure testing and system purging?

choices.b: Dry nitrogen

explanation.short: Dry nitrogen is recommended for pressure testing and purging because it's inert, dry, and safe to release.
explanation.detailed: Nitrogen is preferred because: it's inert (won't react with system components); it's dry (won't add moisture); it's legal to release (not regulated). NEVER use oxygen (explosion risk with oil) or compressed air (contains moisture and contaminants). Use a regulator to prevent over-pressurizing. Nitrogen can be used with a trace of refrigerant for electronic leak detection. Release nitrogen slowly when done.

questions.question: What are common methods for detecting refrigerant leaks?

choices.b: Electronic leak detector, soap bubbles, UV dye, ultrasonic

explanation.short: Leak detection methods include electronic detectors, soap bubbles, UV dye/light, ultrasonic detectors, and visual oil spots.
explanation.detailed: Methods: Electronic detectors - most sensitive, detect refrigerant-specific or halide; Soap bubbles - visual confirmation of leak location; UV dye - added to system, leaks visible under UV light; Ultrasonic - detects sound of leak; Visual - oil spots indicate refrigerant leak (oil travels with refrigerant). Pressurize with nitrogen when possible for better bubble detection. Standing pressure test over time also indicates leaks.

questions.question: How is a standing pressure test performed?

choices.b: Pressurize with nitrogen, isolate, and monitor pressure over time
choices.c: Run the system and check pressures

explanation.short: Pressurize the system with nitrogen, isolate from the nitrogen source, and monitor pressure for any drop over time.
explanation.detailed: Standing pressure test procedure: (1) Pressurize with nitrogen to manufacturer's test pressure or 150% of working pressure; (2) Close valve to isolate from nitrogen source; (3) Monitor pressure for at least 10-15 minutes (longer is better); (4) Any pressure drop indicates a leak. Account for temperature changes affecting pressure. This test confirms system integrity before evacuation and charging.

questions.question: Why should refrigerant be identified before recovery?

choices.b: To avoid contaminating recovery cylinder with mixed or unknown refrigerants

explanation.short: Identifying refrigerant prevents contaminating recovery cylinders with different or unknown refrigerant types.
explanation.detailed: Mixing refrigerants: contaminates entire cylinder contents; requires disposal or special reclaiming; has no resale value. Refrigerant identifiers analyze vapor sample and display refrigerant type and purity. Important when: servicing unfamiliar equipment; refrigerant type isn't labeled; contamination is suspected. Some identifiers detect air contamination too. Cost of identifier is offset by avoiding contaminated cylinder problems.

questions.question: What type of recovery equipment is required when the system's compressor cannot be used?

choices.b: Self-contained (active) recovery equipment

explanation.short: Self-contained recovery equipment has its own compressor and doesn't rely on the system being serviced.
explanation.detailed: Two recovery types: System-dependent - uses the equipment's own compressor (only works if system is operational). Self-contained (active) - has its own compressor and can recover from any system regardless of condition. Self-contained is required when: compressor doesn't work; system has major leak; faster recovery is needed. All recovery equipment must be certified to AHRI 740.

questions.question: What factors affect refrigerant recovery rate?

choices.b: Ambient temperature, hose size, equipment capacity, and remaining system charge

explanation.short: Recovery rate is affected by ambient temperature, hose diameter, recovery equipment capacity, and how much refrigerant remains.
explanation.detailed: Factors affecting recovery speed: Larger hose diameter = faster flow; Warmer ambient = higher system pressure = faster liquid recovery; Recovery equipment capacity (rated in lbs/min); System charge remaining (rate slows as charge decreases); Cylinder back-pressure (cool recovery cylinder to reduce). Short large-diameter hoses with 1/4 inch minimum (3/8 inch preferred) connections speed recovery significantly.

questions.question: What is the fastest method to remove refrigerant from a system?

choices.b: Liquid recovery from the liquid line
choices.c: Recovery from both high and low side

explanation.short: Liquid recovery is faster because liquid refrigerant is denser - more refrigerant moves per unit volume than vapor.
explanation.detailed: Recovery sequence for speed: Start with liquid recovery from liquid line king valve or access fitting - most charge is liquid. When liquid flow stops, switch to vapor recovery from suction side to pull remaining vapor. Push-pull method (for large charges): liquid from system to cylinder while vapor returns from cylinder to system, using pressure differential. Always finish with vapor recovery to reach required vacuum level.

questions.question: Before disposing of refrigeration equipment, what must be done?

choices.b: Recover refrigerant and verify with signed statement

explanation.short: Before disposal, refrigerant must be recovered by a certified technician who signs a statement verifying recovery.
explanation.detailed: Disposal requirements: all refrigerant must be recovered before scrapping; technician must sign statement verifying recovery (or provide reason for exception); applies to any appliance with refrigerant, regardless of charge size. Scrap dealers should verify recovery statement. Penalties for improper disposal can be assessed against owner, technician, or scrap dealer. Exception: de minimis release when using proper recovery equipment.

questions.question: What records must be maintained for equipment containing 50+ lbs of refrigerant?

choices.b: Records of refrigerant additions, service, and leak repairs

explanation.short: Equipment owners must maintain records of refrigerant added, service performed, and leak repairs for systems with 50+ lbs charge.
explanation.detailed: Record requirements for 50+ lb systems: type and amount of refrigerant added; service and repair dates; leak detection and repair records; leak rate calculations. Records must be kept for 3 years. Required for calculating leak rates and demonstrating compliance with repair requirements. Makes owners accountable for system maintenance. Contractors should provide service documentation to owners.

questions.question: How long must technicians keep their EPA 608 certification card?

choices.b: 5 years

explanation.short: EPA 608 certification is permanent and doesn't expire - keep the card indefinitely.
explanation.detailed: Unlike many other certifications, EPA 608 certification doesn't expire. The card should be kept permanently as proof of certification. Technicians can be asked to present certification when purchasing refrigerant or during EPA inspections. If the card is lost, contact the certifying organization for replacement. Certification can be revoked for violations. New certifications may be required for significant rule changes.

questions.question: What is the maximum penalty for knowingly venting refrigerant?

choices.b: $10,000 per occurrence
choices.c: Up to $44,539 per day per violation (adjusted for inflation)

explanation.short: Maximum penalty for venting violations is $44,539 per day per violation, adjusted periodically for inflation.
explanation.detailed: Clean Air Act penalties are substantial and adjusted for inflation. Knowing violations can be criminal, resulting in fines and imprisonment. EPA can assess penalties against: technicians who vent; employers who direct or allow venting; equipment owners who knowingly allow improper practices. Bounty program: informants can receive up to $10,000 for information leading to convictions. Compliance is mandatory, not optional.

questions.question: How does temperature affect refrigerant pressure in a sealed container?

choices.b: Pressure increases as temperature increases

explanation.short: Refrigerant pressure increases as temperature increases - this is the fundamental pressure-temperature relationship.
explanation.detailed: For any pure refrigerant at saturation, there's a fixed relationship between temperature and pressure. Higher temperature = higher molecular energy = higher pressure. This is why: cylinders in sun can become dangerously pressurized; heating refrigerant increases system pressure; cooling the recovery cylinder increases recovery rate. PT (pressure-temperature) charts show these relationships for each refrigerant.

questions.question: What is saturation temperature?

choices.b: The temperature at which refrigerant changes phase at a given pressure

explanation.short: Saturation temperature is the boiling/condensing point of refrigerant at a specific pressure - where liquid and vapor coexist.
explanation.detailed: At saturation, liquid refrigerant boils (evaporates) or vapor condenses at a constant temperature while absorbing or releasing heat. Saturation temperature increases with pressure. Use PT charts to find saturation temp for measured pressure. In evaporator: suction pressure determines evaporating temperature. In condenser: head pressure determines condensing temperature. Superheat and subcooling are measured relative to saturation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a filter drier in a refrigeration system?

choices.b: Remove moisture, acid, and particulates from the refrigerant

explanation.short: Filter driers remove moisture, acids, and particulates that can damage system components.
explanation.detailed: Filter driers have two functions: Filter - remove particulate contamination (from manufacturing, burnout, wear); Drier - desiccant absorbs moisture. Located in liquid line before metering device. Change after: opening system; compressor burnout; major repair. Saturated drier can release contaminants back into system. Driers are sized for refrigerant type and charge. Bi-directional driers are available for heat pumps.

questions.question: What does a moisture indicator in a sight glass show?

choices.b: Color change indicating wet (moisture present) or dry conditions

explanation.short: The moisture indicator dot changes color: typically green = dry, yellow = moisture present (wet).
explanation.detailed: Liquid line sight glasses often have a moisture-indicating element. Color code varies by manufacturer but commonly: Green = dry (acceptable moisture level); Yellow = wet (excessive moisture - change drier). The indicator is reactive - it shows current moisture level, not historical. After system repair and new drier installation, monitor indicator to confirm drier is effective. Also observe for bubbles indicating low charge or restriction.

questions.question: After a hermetic compressor burnout, what special procedures are required?

choices.b: Thorough system cleanup: recover refrigerant, replace drier(s), acid test, flush, and multiple drier changes until acid-free

explanation.short: Compressor burnout produces acids that contaminate the entire system; thorough cleanup is required for the new compressor to survive.
explanation.detailed: Burnout cleanup: (1) Recover contaminated refrigerant (cannot be reused); (2) Replace line-side and suction filter driers; (3) Install new compressor; (4) Evacuate thoroughly; (5) Charge and run; (6) Acid test oil after 24-48 hours; (7) If acid present, change driers, run, retest; (8) Repeat until acid-free. May take multiple drier changes. Failure to clean results in repeat burnout. Flush coils if heavily contaminated.

questions.question: What type of oil is used with CFC and HCFC refrigerants?

choices.b: Mineral oil or alkylbenzene

explanation.short: CFC and HCFC refrigerants are miscible with mineral oil and alkylbenzene (AB) lubricants.
explanation.detailed: Oil compatibility by refrigerant: CFCs (R-12, R-11) = mineral oil; HCFCs (R-22) = mineral oil or alkylbenzene; HFCs (R-410A, R-134a) = POE or PVE (synthetic); Ammonia = mineral oil; CO2 = PAG or POE. Using wrong oil causes: poor lubrication, oil logging in evaporator, compressor failure. Never mix oil types unless specifically approved by manufacturer.

questions.question: How is proper compressor oil level typically verified?

choices.b: Oil sight glass on compressor (if equipped), or measuring oil removed vs. added

explanation.short: Check oil level via sight glass on compressor crankcase (larger units) or by measuring oil removed and added during service.
explanation.detailed: Oil level monitoring: Compressor sight glass - if equipped, check level during operation (should be 1/4 to 3/4 full). During service - measure oil removed from system and add equivalent amount. Too little oil = compressor wear and failure. Too much oil = oil logging in evaporator, reduced capacity. Factory charge typically correct for line-set lengths; add oil for longer runs per manufacturer specs.

questions.question: What should NEVER be done with refrigerant cylinders?

choices.b: Heat with open flame or drop to empty faster

explanation.short: Never heat cylinders with open flame, drop them, or overfill them - these can cause explosive rupture.
explanation.detailed: Dangerous cylinder practices: Heating with flame or excessive heat (can raise pressure to rupture point); Dropping (damages cylinder and valve); Overfilling (no expansion space = hydrostatic rupture when heated); Using disposable cylinders for recovery (not rated for refilling); Transporting without securing (can become projectile). Treat cylinders carefully - they're pressure vessels. Store away from heat sources.

questions.question: What is the maximum refrigerant charge for a small appliance (Type I equipment)?

choices.b: 5 lbs

explanation.short: Small appliances are defined as having 5 lbs or less of refrigerant charge.
explanation.detailed: Type I certification covers small appliances with a factory charge of 5 lbs or less that are manufactured, charged, and hermetically sealed in a factory. Examples: household refrigerators, window AC units, PTACs under 5 lbs, dehumidifiers, vending machines, drinking water coolers. These appliances typically have no service valves and require different recovery techniques.

questions.question: What is the required recovery efficiency for small appliances when the compressor is operating?

explanation.short: When the compressor operates, recovery equipment must recover 90% of the refrigerant from small appliances.
explanation.detailed: Small appliance recovery requirements: With operating compressor = 90% recovery; With non-operating compressor = 80% recovery OR 4 inches Hg vacuum (whichever is less). These percentages were established because small appliances often have no service access valves, making complete recovery difficult. Self-contained recovery equipment designed for small appliances must meet these standards.

questions.question: How is refrigerant typically accessed in small appliances without service valves?

choices.b: By installing a piercing access valve (bullet valve)

explanation.short: Piercing access valves (bullet valves or line tap valves) are installed on the process tube to access refrigerant.
explanation.detailed: Most small appliances have no service valves - the system is sealed at the factory. To recover refrigerant: install a self-sealing piercing valve (saddle valve or bullet valve) on the process tube or compressor stub tube. These valves pierce the tubing when tightened and provide a service port. After recovery, the valve stays in place. Some technicians also cut and crimp/braze the process tube.

questions.question: What type of equipment does Type III certification cover?

choices.b: High-pressure systems using R-410A

explanation.short: Type III covers low-pressure equipment - centrifugal chillers using refrigerants like R-11, R-123, and R-245fa.
explanation.detailed: Low-pressure refrigerants have boiling points above 50°F at atmospheric pressure. Examples: R-11 (boils at 74°F), R-123 (boils at 82°F). This means systems often operate below atmospheric pressure (in vacuum), presenting unique challenges: air can leak INTO the system; special purge units remove non-condensables; recovery requires different techniques. Found in large commercial centrifugal chillers.

questions.question: Why do low-pressure refrigeration systems often operate in a vacuum?

choices.b: Because the refrigerant boiling point is above normal operating temperatures at atmospheric pressure

explanation.short: Low-pressure refrigerants have high boiling points, so pressure must be reduced (vacuum) to achieve desired evaporating temperatures.
explanation.detailed: R-123 boils at 82°F at atmospheric pressure. To produce 40°F chilled water, the evaporator must operate at lower pressure - about 6 inches Hg vacuum for R-123. This means: air/moisture can leak IN through any opening; systems need purge units to remove non-condensables; special leak detection is required (you can't always feel leaks with positive pressure).

questions.question: What is the purpose of a purge unit on a low-pressure chiller?

choices.b: To remove non-condensables (air) that leak into the system

explanation.short: Purge units automatically remove air and non-condensable gases that leak into low-pressure systems operating below atmospheric pressure.
explanation.detailed: Because low-pressure systems operate in vacuum, air leaks IN rather than refrigerant leaking out. Air (non-condensable) accumulates in the condenser, raising head pressure and reducing efficiency. High-efficiency purge units: collect non-condensables; separate them from refrigerant; release air while minimizing refrigerant loss. Older purge units could lose significant refrigerant; modern units lose less than 0.5 lb per pound of air purged.

questions.question: What is the required recovery level for low-pressure equipment manufactured after January 1, 1992?

choices.b: 25 mm Hg absolute

explanation.short: Low-pressure systems manufactured after 1/1/92 must be recovered to 25 mm Hg absolute (about 29 inches Hg vacuum).
explanation.detailed: Recovery requirements for Type III (low-pressure) using equipment manufactured after November 15, 1993: Equipment made after 1/1/92 = 25 mm Hg absolute; Equipment made before 1/1/92 = 25 inches Hg vacuum relative. 25 mm Hg absolute is approximately 29 inches Hg vacuum. These deep vacuums are needed because low-pressure refrigerant naturally wants to vaporize at room temperature.

questions.question: What is the ASHRAE 34 safety classification of R-123?

choices.b: B1

explanation.short: R-123 is classified B1 - higher toxicity (B) but non-flammable (1).
explanation.detailed: R-123 (HCFC-123) was developed as a safer replacement for R-11 in centrifugal chillers. While non-flammable (1), it has higher toxicity (B) than R-11. The AEL (Allowable Exposure Limit) is 50 ppm. Symptoms of overexposure include CNS effects. Chillers using R-123 require: room sensors; ventilation; and may require refrigerant monitors per ASHRAE 15. Exposure limits must be followed.

questions.question: What is the primary safety hazard when refrigerant is released in an enclosed space?

choices.b: Oxygen displacement leading to asphyxiation

explanation.short: Refrigerant vapors are heavier than air and can displace oxygen in enclosed or low-lying areas, causing asphyxiation.
explanation.detailed: Most refrigerants are heavier than air (R-410A is about 3x heavier). In enclosed spaces: refrigerant settles to lowest points; displaces breathable air; can cause asphyxiation without warning (most refrigerants are odorless). Safety measures: adequate ventilation; self-contained breathing apparatus for confined spaces; refrigerant monitors in mechanical rooms; never work alone in confined spaces with refrigerant.

questions.question: What injury can occur from contact with liquid refrigerant?

choices.b: Frostbite due to rapid evaporation and cooling

explanation.short: Liquid refrigerant rapidly evaporates on contact, absorbing heat and causing frostbite to skin and eyes.
explanation.detailed: When liquid refrigerant contacts skin or eyes, it absorbs heat of vaporization from tissue, causing: immediate freezing; frostbite; permanent eye damage. Safety precautions: wear safety glasses/goggles; wear gloves when handling liquid; if contact occurs, flush with tepid water (not hot); seek medical attention for eye exposure or severe frostbite. Never release liquid refrigerant quickly.

questions.question: What toxic gas can be produced when halogenated refrigerants contact open flames?

choices.b: Hydrogen sulfide
choices.c: Phosgene and other toxic decomposition products

explanation.short: Halogenated refrigerants (containing chlorine, fluorine) decompose at high temperatures to produce phosgene and other toxic gases.
explanation.detailed: When CFCs, HCFCs, or HFCs contact temperatures above 1000°F (open flame, electric arc, glowing heater): they decompose into phosgene (COCl2), hydrogen fluoride, and other toxic compounds. These are extremely hazardous. Never: braze with refrigerant in system; smoke around refrigerants; use halide torch leak detectors near flames. If decomposition products are smelled (sharp, acrid odor), leave area immediately and ventilate.

questions.question: What respiratory protection is appropriate when working with refrigerants in confined spaces?

choices.b: Standard half-face respirator
choices.c: Self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) or supplied air

explanation.short: Self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) or supplied air respirator is required because refrigerants displace oxygen rather than being filtered.
explanation.detailed: Standard respirators filter contaminants from air but cannot supply oxygen. Refrigerants don't filter out - they displace oxygen. In confined spaces or areas with possible high refrigerant concentration: SCBA provides independent air supply; supplied air respirator connects to clean air source; both provide breathing air regardless of local atmosphere. Required when entering spaces where oxygen may be depleted.

questions.question: What is a de minimis release under EPA 608?

choices.b: Small unavoidable releases during good-faith efforts to recover refrigerant

explanation.short: De minimis releases are small, unavoidable refrigerant emissions that occur when making good-faith efforts to recover and recycle.
explanation.detailed: De minimis means 'too small to be of concern.' Under EPA 608, de minimis releases are permitted when: properly recovering refrigerant; connecting/disconnecting hoses; using proper equipment. NOT de minimis: intentionally venting; not recovering before repair; using refrigerant for cleaning. The technician must make a good-faith effort to capture refrigerant. De minimis is about technique, not quantity.

questions.question: What determines if equipment is classified as commercial refrigeration for EPA leak repair purposes?

choices.b: Equipment used for storing/dispensing food for sale or in commercial operations

explanation.short: Commercial refrigeration includes equipment for storing, displaying, or dispensing food/beverages in commercial applications.
explanation.detailed: Commercial refrigeration includes: supermarket display cases; walk-in coolers/freezers in restaurants; ice machines in commercial use; cold storage warehouses; vending machines (commercial). 20% annual leak rate triggers repair requirement. Comfort cooling (AC systems) wasn't covered until AIM Act added 10% threshold for systems with 50+ lbs. Industrial process refrigeration has 30% threshold.

questions.question: A commercial refrigeration system has 100 lbs full charge. Over the past year, 30 lbs of refrigerant was added. What is the annual leak rate?

explanation.short: Leak rate = (refrigerant added / full charge) × 100 = (30 lbs / 100 lbs) × 100 = 30%
explanation.detailed: Annual leak rate calculation: Total refrigerant added over 365 days ÷ total full charge × 100. In this case: 30 lbs ÷ 100 lbs = 0.30 = 30%. At 30% leak rate, commercial refrigeration exceeds the 20% repair trigger. Owner must: identify and repair leak within 30 days; OR develop a retrofit/retirement plan. Document all additions with dates and amounts for accurate tracking.

questions.question: How many days does an owner have to repair a leak after exceeding the leak rate threshold?

choices.b: 30 days

explanation.short: Owners have 30 days from discovering they exceed the leak rate threshold to repair leaks.
explanation.detailed: Repair timeline: within 30 days of discovery that leak rate is exceeded. If repair requires custom parts, extension to 120 days may be allowed. If leak cannot be repaired, owner must: submit retrofit/retirement plan within 30 days; execute plan within 180 days. Verification test required within 30 days of repair to confirm success. These requirements ensure leaks don't go unaddressed.

questions.question: What is a retrofit in refrigeration system terms?

choices.b: Converting a system to use a different refrigerant

explanation.short: A retrofit converts an existing system to use a different refrigerant, often to comply with phaseout requirements.
explanation.detailed: Retrofit involves: recovering existing refrigerant; making necessary component changes (metering device, seals, oil); recharging with new refrigerant. Common retrofits: R-22 to R-407C or R-422D (drop-in or near-drop-in). Retrofit considerations: compatibility of new refrigerant with existing components; oil compatibility; capacity and efficiency changes; relabeling system with new refrigerant type. Not all systems are good retrofit candidates.

questions.question: What is a 'drop-in' replacement refrigerant?

choices.a: Refrigerant that is identical to the original
choices.b: Alternative refrigerant requiring no component changes, just refrigerant replacement

explanation.short: A drop-in replacement can be used with minimal or no system modifications - just evacuate old refrigerant and charge new.
explanation.detailed: Drop-in refrigerants are alternatives that work in existing systems with few or no changes. True drop-ins are rare. 'Near-drop-ins' may require: oil change; TXV adjustment; minor component changes. Examples: some R-407C as R-22 replacement (but not truly a drop-in - oil change often needed). Always verify manufacturer approval. Performance and efficiency may differ from original refrigerant.

questions.question: What is the difference between zeotropic and azeotropic refrigerant blends?

choices.b: Zeotropes fractionate; azeotropes behave like single-component refrigerants

explanation.short: Zeotropic blends can separate (fractionate) at different rates; azeotropic blends evaporate/condense together like pure refrigerants.
explanation.detailed: Azeotropic blends (R-502, R-507): components evaporate/condense together; single boiling point; can charge as liquid or vapor; no fractionation concern. Zeotropic blends (R-410A, R-407C): components have different volatility; glide (temperature difference during phase change); MUST charge as liquid to maintain composition; fractionation possible with leaks. Near-azeotropes (R-410A) have minimal glide but still require liquid charging.

questions.question: What is temperature glide in zeotropic refrigerant blends?

choices.b: The temperature difference between bubble and dew point during phase change

explanation.short: Temperature glide is the range between the bubble point (all liquid) and dew point (all vapor) during phase change.
explanation.detailed: Pure refrigerants and azeotropes change phase at a constant temperature. Zeotropes have temperature glide: liquid starts boiling at bubble point; continues through two-phase region; finishes at dew point (all vapor). R-407C has about 10°F glide; R-410A has <1°F (near-azeotrope). Glide affects: superheat/subcooling measurements (must specify bubble or dew); heat exchanger design; system performance.

questions.question: What EPA program lists acceptable substitute refrigerants?

choices.b: SNAP (Significant New Alternatives Policy)

explanation.short: The SNAP program evaluates and lists acceptable substitute refrigerants for various applications.
explanation.detailed: SNAP (Significant New Alternatives Policy) under Clean Air Act Section 612: evaluates substitutes for ozone-depleting substances; publishes lists of acceptable and unacceptable alternatives; specific to end-use sectors (AC, refrigeration, foam, etc.). SNAP approval needed before using alternative refrigerant. Lists updated as new refrigerants are evaluated. Acceptability may be conditional (requires specific safety measures).

questions.question: What are the key characteristics of R-32 as an R-410A replacement?

choices.b: Lower GWP (675 vs 2088), A2L mildly flammable, single-component

explanation.short: R-32 has GWP of 675 (vs R-410A's 2088), is A2L (mildly flammable), and is a single-component refrigerant.
explanation.detailed: R-32 properties: GWP = 675 (68% lower than R-410A); A2L classification (lower flammability - ignites with difficulty, burns slowly); single component (no fractionation, can charge vapor); similar pressures to R-410A; slightly higher discharge temperature. Used in mini-splits and some unitary equipment. Requires safety measures for A2L but less restrictive than A2/A3. Major R-410A alternative outside North America.

questions.question: What is R-454B and why is it significant?

choices.b: An A2L low-GWP blend being adopted as primary R-410A replacement in US

explanation.short: R-454B (Opteon XL41) is a low-GWP A2L blend being adopted as the main R-410A replacement in US residential HVAC.
explanation.detailed: R-454B characteristics: GWP = 466 (78% lower than R-410A); A2L safety classification; blend of R-32 and R-1234yf; similar capacity and efficiency to R-410A; slightly lower operating pressures. Selected by major US HVAC manufacturers for residential equipment starting 2025. Requires A2L-compliant equipment, installation practices, and service procedures. Training on A2L refrigerants is essential for technicians.

questions.question: What refrigerant is R-290?

choices.b: Propane - a natural hydrocarbon refrigerant

explanation.short: R-290 is propane, a natural hydrocarbon refrigerant with very low GWP but high flammability (A3).
explanation.detailed: R-290 (propane) properties: GWP = 3 (extremely low); ODP = 0; A3 classification (highly flammable); excellent thermodynamic properties; low charge required. Used in: self-contained commercial refrigeration; some small residential AC in Europe/Asia; domestic refrigerators. US use limited due to flammability but expanding with charge limits (150g for some applications). Requires special safety training, equipment, and installation practices.

questions.question: What is unique about CO2 (R-744) as a refrigerant?

choices.b: GWP of 1, operates at very high pressures, transcritical operation

explanation.short: CO2 (R-744) has GWP of 1, ODP of 0, but operates at very high pressures (1000+ psi) and often transcritically.
explanation.detailed: R-744 (CO2) characteristics: GWP = 1 (baseline); ODP = 0; A1 (non-toxic, non-flammable); critical point 88°F/1070 psi - often operates transcritically (above critical point); operating pressures 10x higher than R-410A. Used in: commercial refrigeration (Europe especially); cascade systems; heat pump water heaters. Requires special high-pressure components and different system design. Growing use due to ultra-low GWP.

questions.question: What is the safety classification of ammonia (R-717)?

choices.b: A2L

explanation.short: Ammonia (R-717) is classified B2L - higher toxicity (B) and lower flammability (2L).
explanation.detailed: Ammonia properties: ODP = 0; GWP = 0; natural refrigerant; excellent thermodynamic properties; B2L classification (toxic at 25 ppm, mildly flammable). Used in large industrial refrigeration (cold storage, ice rinks, food processing). Requires: special training; safety equipment; machinery room ventilation; ammonia detectors; emergency procedures. Not used in comfort cooling due to toxicity. Self-alarming (strong odor detectable at safe levels).

questions.question: By what percentage must HFC production and consumption be reduced by 2036 under the AIM Act?

explanation.short: The AIM Act requires an 85% phasedown of HFC production and consumption by 2036 from the 2011-2013 baseline.
explanation.detailed: AIM Act HFC phasedown schedule (from 2011-2013 baseline): 2022-2023: 90% of baseline; 2024-2028: 60% of baseline; 2029-2033: 30% of baseline; 2034-2035: 20% of baseline; 2036+: 15% of baseline (85% reduction). This drives transition to low-GWP alternatives. EPA allocates allowances to producers/importers. High-GWP refrigerants like R-410A will become increasingly scarce and expensive.

questions.question: What EPA certification is required for motor vehicle air conditioning?

choices.b: EPA 609

explanation.short: EPA Section 609 certification is specifically required for servicing motor vehicle air conditioning systems.
explanation.detailed: EPA 609 (Section 609 of Clean Air Act) covers: passenger car AC; light truck AC; heavy-duty vehicle AC. Separate from Section 608 which covers stationary equipment. Technicians need 609 for MVAC AND may need 608 for stationary equipment. 609 certification requires: passing EPA-approved exam; using approved recovery/recycling equipment; keeping service records. Self-sealing hose fittings required.

questions.question: What is MVAC-like equipment?

choices.b: AC systems on agricultural/construction equipment using same refrigerant as passenger cars

explanation.short: MVAC-like equipment includes AC on farm tractors, construction vehicles, and similar off-road equipment using automotive-type refrigerants.
explanation.detailed: MVAC-like appliances: mechanically similar to passenger car AC; use same refrigerant (typically R-134a); found on agricultural equipment, construction machinery, boats. EPA 608 certification (not 609) required to service MVAC-like equipment. However, same recovery requirements as MVAC apply. Important distinction: farm tractor = MVAC-like (608); pickup truck = MVAC (609).

questions.question: What is system-dependent recovery equipment?

choices.a: Equipment that has its own compressor
choices.b: Equipment that relies on the appliance's compressor or pressure for recovery

explanation.short: System-dependent recovery uses the appliance's own compressor or internal pressure to push refrigerant into the recovery cylinder.
explanation.detailed: System-dependent (passive) recovery: uses appliance's compressor to pump refrigerant into receiver; or uses pressure differential between system and recovery cylinder (for non-operating systems). Limitations: only works if system operates; slower than active recovery; may not achieve required vacuum levels. Self-contained (active) recovery has its own compressor and is preferred for most applications.

questions.question: What type of hose fittings minimize refrigerant loss during connection/disconnection?

choices.b: Low-loss or self-sealing fittings

explanation.short: Low-loss or self-sealing fittings have valves that close when disconnected, minimizing refrigerant release.
explanation.detailed: Low-loss (self-sealing) fittings: have valve cores that close automatically when hose is disconnected; minimize de minimis releases; required for MVAC service; best practice for all refrigerant work. Standard hoses can release refrigerant trapped between fitting and core depressor. Good practice: use low-loss fittings; close manifold valves before disconnecting; minimize hose length to reduce trapped volume.

questions.question: How does hose diameter affect recovery speed?

choices.b: Larger diameter = faster recovery due to less flow restriction

explanation.short: Larger diameter hoses have less flow restriction, allowing faster refrigerant flow and quicker recovery.
explanation.detailed: Recovery speed factors: Hose inside diameter - larger = faster (3/8 inch better than 1/4 inch); Hose length - shorter = faster (less pressure drop); Number of connections - fewer = faster. For fast recovery from large systems: use 3/8 inch or larger hoses; keep hoses short; minimize fittings. Recovery rate can more than double going from 1/4 inch to 3/8 inch hose.

questions.question: What is the push-pull recovery method?

choices.b: Liquid recovery using pressure differential, with vapor returning to system

explanation.short: Push-pull uses recovery machine to create pressure differential: liquid flows from system to cylinder while vapor returns to system.
explanation.detailed: Push-pull recovery for large charges: Recovery machine pushes vapor into system liquid line; Increased pressure pushes liquid refrigerant out through separate connection; Liquid flows to recovery cylinder; Vapor from cylinder returns to system. Continuous circulation until mostly liquid is recovered. Then switch to standard vapor recovery to complete. Very fast for large charges (hundreds of pounds).

questions.question: How do non-condensable gases (air) affect system operation?

choices.b: Increase head pressure and reduce capacity/efficiency

explanation.short: Non-condensables like air don't condense in the condenser, raising head pressure and reducing system capacity and efficiency.
explanation.detailed: Air in refrigeration system effects: accumulates in condenser (highest pressure point); takes up condenser space that should be for refrigerant; doesn't condense - maintains its own partial pressure; raises total head pressure; reduces subcooling; system works harder for less cooling. Sources: improper evacuation; leaks during vacuum; contaminated refrigerant. Remove by proper evacuation before charging.

questions.question: What is triple evacuation and when is it used?

choices.b: Evacuate, break vacuum with nitrogen, evacuate, repeat - for stubborn moisture
choices.d: Evacuating three times without breaking vacuum

explanation.short: Triple evacuation involves evacuating, breaking vacuum with dry nitrogen, and repeating to remove stubborn moisture.
explanation.detailed: Triple evacuation procedure: (1) Evacuate to 1500 microns; (2) Break vacuum with dry nitrogen to about 2 psig; (3) Evacuate to 500 microns; (4) Break vacuum with nitrogen again; (5) Final evacuation to 500 microns and hold. Nitrogen helps: absorb moisture from surfaces; dilute moisture for faster removal; verify no leaks (should hold pressure). Used when moisture contamination is suspected or for critical systems.

questions.question: What does a rising vacuum (micron) reading indicate during a standing vacuum test?

choices.b: Leak, residual moisture vaporizing, or outgassing

explanation.short: Rising microns after isolating the pump indicate a leak, remaining moisture evaporating, or material outgassing.
explanation.detailed: Standing vacuum test interpretation: Rapid rise = leak (air entering system); Slow rise leveling off = moisture evaporating (continue evacuation); Rise then stop = outgassing from oil or materials. Procedure: pull to 500 microns; isolate pump; wait 10+ minutes. Good system: stays below 1000 microns. If rises above 1500 microns, investigate before charging. Distinguish leak from moisture by whether rise continues or levels off.

questions.question: Why should vacuum pump oil be changed regularly?

choices.b: Oil absorbs moisture and contaminants, reducing pump efficiency

explanation.short: Vacuum pump oil absorbs moisture and contaminants from evacuated systems, which reduces its ability to achieve deep vacuum.
explanation.detailed: Vacuum pump oil maintenance: Oil absorbs moisture and refrigerant; contaminated oil can't achieve deep vacuum; milky or discolored oil = contaminated. Change oil: after heavy use; when appearance changes; before critical evacuation; if pump won't achieve rated vacuum. Use oil designed for vacuum pumps. Run pump with gas ballast open periodically to purge moisture. Some pumps have sight glass to monitor oil condition.

questions.question: After retrofitting a system to a different refrigerant, what must be done?

choices.b: Apply new label showing current refrigerant type and oil

explanation.short: The system must be relabeled to show the new refrigerant type and any oil changes made during retrofit.
explanation.detailed: Retrofit labeling requirements: remove or cover old refrigerant label; apply new label with: refrigerant type, oil type, date of retrofit, technician name/company. Important for future service - wrong refrigerant or oil can damage system. Labels should be durable and visible. Color coding may change (R-22 = green, R-410A = pink). Also update service records.

questions.question: How should used refrigerant oil be disposed of?

choices.b: As hazardous waste or through approved recycling

explanation.short: Used refrigerant oil may be hazardous waste and should be disposed through approved channels, not down drains.
explanation.detailed: Used oil disposal: may contain refrigerant, acids, and contaminants; don't pour down drains (environmental contamination); don't mix with motor oil (different recycling); collect in approved containers; dispose through hazardous waste facility or oil recycler that accepts refrigerant oil. Oil from burnout is especially hazardous. Keep records of disposal. Local regulations may have additional requirements.

questions.question: What types of appliances does EPA Section 608 regulate?

choices.b: Stationary refrigeration and air conditioning equipment

explanation.short: EPA 608 covers all stationary refrigeration and air conditioning equipment, from small appliances to large chillers.
explanation.detailed: Section 608 scope includes: residential AC and heat pumps; commercial refrigeration; industrial refrigeration and process cooling; chillers; ice machines; dehumidifiers; refrigerators and freezers (all sizes). Excludes: motor vehicle AC (covered by Section 609); some exempt substitutes. The venting prohibition and recovery requirements apply to all regulated refrigerants in stationary equipment.

questions.question: Under what circumstances must refrigerant releases be reported to EPA?

choices.b: Only intentional venting
choices.c: Releases of 100 lbs or more of certain ODS within 24 hours from any source

explanation.short: Releases of 100 lbs or more of ODS refrigerant within 24 hours from any source require notification to EPA.
explanation.detailed: Reporting requirements under CERCLA/SARA: release of 100 lbs or more of certain ODS refrigerants within 24 hours requires notification to National Response Center. This applies to: accidents; equipment failures; catastrophic releases. Normal service operations with proper recovery don't trigger this. For HFCs, different thresholds may apply. Document significant releases even if below threshold.

questions.question: Who is ultimately responsible for compliance with refrigerant management requirements?

choices.b: Only the EPA
choices.c: Both equipment owners and technicians have responsibilities

explanation.short: Both equipment owners and service technicians have specific responsibilities under EPA regulations.
explanation.detailed: Shared responsibility: Owners must: maintain leak records (50+ lb systems); ensure repairs when leak rate exceeded; use certified technicians; keep service records; properly dispose of equipment. Technicians must: be certified; use certified recovery equipment; recover before service; not vent; document refrigerant transactions. Penalties can apply to both parties for non-compliance.

questions.question: Which substances are NOT regulated under Section 608 venting prohibition?

choices.c: Ammonia, CO2, water, nitrogen, and certain low-GWP substitutes

explanation.short: Some refrigerants like ammonia, CO2, water, and nitrogen are exempt from the venting prohibition.
explanation.detailed: Exempt from 608 venting prohibition: ammonia; carbon dioxide; water; nitrogen; hydrocarbons in limited applications. Note that many of these have other safety requirements (ammonia is toxic). The AIM Act extended regulation to HFCs. Exempt doesn't mean unregulated for safety - just not subject to EPA 608 recovery requirements. Always follow safe handling practices for any refrigerant.

questions.question: Who administers EPA Section 608 technician certification exams?

choices.b: EPA-approved certifying organizations

explanation.short: EPA-approved certifying organizations administer the Section 608 certification exams.
explanation.detailed: Certification process: EPA approves organizations to administer exams; organizations develop tests meeting EPA criteria; exams can be proctored in-person or online with proctoring; passing score typically 70% or higher. Common certifying organizations include: ESCO, RSES, HVAC Excellence, NATE. Organizations issue certification cards. Certification is nationwide - not state-specific.

questions.question: What sections must be passed for Universal EPA 608 certification?

choices.b: Type II only
choices.c: Core plus Type I, Type II, and Type III

explanation.short: Universal certification requires passing the Core section plus all three type-specific sections (I, II, and III).
explanation.detailed: EPA 608 exam structure: Core - general knowledge required for all types; Type I - small appliances; Type II - high-pressure equipment; Type III - low-pressure equipment. To earn Universal: pass Core + Type I + Type II + Type III. To earn specific type: pass Core + that type's section. Most HVAC technicians get Universal or at minimum Type II (covers most AC/refrigeration work).

questions.question: Can apprentices work on refrigerant systems without EPA 608 certification?

choices.b: Yes, if supervised by a certified technician who is present
choices.c: Yes, for the first year only

explanation.short: Uncertified individuals may work on systems if a certified technician is present and supervising.
explanation.detailed: Apprentice/training exception: uncertified persons may perform service if: certified technician is on-site; certified technician supervises the work; certified technician is immediately available. The certified technician is responsible for ensuring proper procedures. This allows training while maintaining compliance. However, certification is needed to work independently or purchase refrigerant.

questions.question: What special precautions are required when working with A2L refrigerants?

choices.b: Eliminate ignition sources, ensure ventilation, use A2L-rated equipment

explanation.short: A2L refrigerants require elimination of ignition sources, adequate ventilation, and use of equipment rated for flammable refrigerants.
explanation.detailed: A2L safety requirements: No open flames or ignition sources during service; Adequate ventilation (natural or mechanical); Use recovery equipment rated for flammable refrigerants; Detect-and-alarm tools available; No sparking electrical devices; Training on flammable refrigerant handling. While A2L has lower flammability than A2/A3, it can still ignite under right conditions. Equipment design includes charge limits and safety features.

questions.question: What DOT requirement applies to transporting refrigerant cylinders?

choices.b: Cylinders must be secured, upright, and valve protected during transport

explanation.short: DOT requires cylinders be secured to prevent movement, kept upright when possible, with valve protection caps in place.
explanation.detailed: Cylinder transport safety: Secure cylinders to prevent rolling/falling; Valve protection caps in place; Store in well-ventilated area (vehicle); Don't exceed vehicle capacity; Disposable cylinders under 1000 lbs total may use limited quantity exception; Larger quantities need placarding/shipping papers. Cylinders are pressure vessels - damage can be catastrophic. Never transport in passenger compartment.

questions.question: What incentive exists for reporting EPA refrigerant violations?

choices.b: Informants may receive up to $10,000 for information leading to conviction

explanation.short: EPA offers up to $10,000 to informants who provide information leading to successful enforcement action.
explanation.detailed: EPA bounty program: rewards up to $10,000 for tips leading to conviction; covers venting violations, selling to uncertified persons, failure to recover, false documentation. Reports can be anonymous. This program encourages compliance and reporting of violators. Information can be reported to EPA regional offices or tip lines. Program reinforces that violations have consequences.

questions.question: What must be installed when access to system refrigerant is created?

choices.b: A service aperture (access fitting) must be brazed or permanently attached

explanation.short: When creating access to a sealed system, a service aperture (fitting) must be permanently installed using brazed or similar connections.
explanation.detailed: Service aperture requirements: when accessing factory-sealed systems (small appliances), the access fitting must be brazed, soldered, or otherwise permanently attached. This ensures: future service can be performed; system remains sealed when not being serviced; no temporary holes left in system. Self-sealing quick-connect fittings are acceptable. Process tubes may be pinched and brazed after recovery.

questions.question: Why are CFCs more damaging to the ozone layer than HCFCs?

choices.b: CFCs are more stable and release chlorine in the stratosphere more efficiently

explanation.short: CFCs are more stable and survive long enough to reach the stratosphere where they release chlorine that destroys ozone.
explanation.detailed: CFC vs HCFC ozone impact: CFCs have no hydrogen, making them very stable; they survive to reach stratosphere intact; UV light breaks them down, releasing chlorine; chlorine destroys ozone in catalytic cycle. HCFCs contain hydrogen, making them less stable; most break down in troposphere before reaching stratosphere; ODP of HCFCs is 2-10% of CFCs. This is why HCFC phaseout was slower than CFC phaseout.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference CFC stability and ozone damage

questions.question: How many ozone molecules can one chlorine atom destroy?

explanation.short: A single chlorine atom can destroy 100,000 or more ozone molecules through a catalytic chain reaction.
explanation.detailed: Chlorine ozone destruction cycle: (1) Chlorine atom + ozone → chlorine monoxide + oxygen; (2) Chlorine monoxide + oxygen atom → chlorine atom + oxygen molecule; (3) Regenerated chlorine atom repeats the process. This catalytic cycle continues until chlorine is deactivated by other reactions. One chlorine atom persists in stratosphere for years, destroying enormous amounts of ozone. This is why even small CFC releases are significant.

questions.question: What human health effects result from increased UV radiation due to ozone depletion?

choices.b: Skin cancer, cataracts, and immune system suppression

explanation.short: Increased UV-B radiation from ozone depletion causes skin cancer, cataracts, and weakened immune systems.
explanation.detailed: Health effects of UV-B increase: skin cancer (melanoma and non-melanoma); cataracts and other eye damage; suppressed immune response. Environmental effects: reduced crop yields; damage to marine ecosystems (phytoplankton); degradation of plastics and materials. These consequences drove international action on ozone protection (Montreal Protocol). Protecting the ozone layer protects human and environmental health.

questions.question: What is the Montreal Protocol?

choices.b: International treaty to phase out ozone-depleting substances

explanation.short: The Montreal Protocol is an international treaty signed in 1987 that established schedules for phasing out ozone-depleting substances globally.
explanation.detailed: Montreal Protocol (1987): international agreement to protect ozone layer; 197 countries ratified (universal ratification); established ODS phaseout schedules; has been amended multiple times (London, Copenhagen, Kigali); Kigali Amendment (2016) added HFC phasedown. Considered most successful environmental treaty in history. US Clean Air Act implements Montreal Protocol requirements domestically.

questions.question: What did the Kigali Amendment add to the Montreal Protocol?

choices.b: HFC phasedown schedule to address climate change

explanation.short: The Kigali Amendment (2016) added HFC phasedown schedules to address the high global warming potential of HFC refrigerants.
explanation.detailed: Kigali Amendment (2016): recognizes HFCs' climate impact (high GWP); establishes global HFC phasedown; different schedules for developed and developing countries; goal to avoid 0.5°C warming by 2100; US ratified and implemented through AIM Act. This connects refrigerant management to both ozone protection AND climate change mitigation. Drives transition to low-GWP alternatives.

questions.question: A small appliance has 3 lbs of refrigerant. Using system-dependent recovery with an operating compressor, what is the minimum amount that must be recovered?

choices.b: 2.7 lbs

explanation.short: 90% recovery required with operating compressor: 3 lbs × 0.90 = 2.7 lbs minimum.
explanation.detailed: Small appliance recovery calculation: with operating compressor, 90% recovery required. 3 lbs × 90% = 2.7 lbs minimum. With non-operating compressor, 80% or 4 inches Hg vacuum required (whichever results in less recovery). Always try to recover as much as possible - these are minimums. Self-contained recovery equipment typically achieves better recovery than system-dependent.

questions.question: What are important characteristics of R-407C as an R-22 replacement?

choices.b: Zeotropic blend with temperature glide, requires POE oil, lower capacity

explanation.short: R-407C is a zeotropic blend with significant temperature glide, requires POE oil, and has slightly lower capacity than R-22.
explanation.detailed: R-407C characteristics: blend of R-32/R-125/R-134a; zeotropic with 8-10°F glide; must charge as liquid; requires POE oil (not mineral); ODP = 0; GWP = 1774; similar pressures to R-22; 5-10% capacity reduction typical. Not a true drop-in - requires: oil change; possible TXV adjustment; expansion device compatibility check. Performance varies by application. Label system after retrofit.

questions.question: What can cause a leak at a flare fitting connection?

choices.b: Under-torque, over-torque, misalignment, or damaged flare

explanation.short: Flare leaks result from improper torque (under or over), misalignment of tubing, or damaged/improperly formed flares.
explanation.detailed: Flare connection leak causes: Under-torque - insufficient sealing force; Over-torque - cracked flare nut, deformed flare; Misaligned tubing - uneven seal pressure; Scratched or nicked flare - can't seal properly; Wrong flare angle (SAE vs ISO); Contamination (debris, oil) on sealing surface. Prevention: proper flare technique; correct torque; use two wrenches (back-up); inspect flares before assembly.

questions.question: What is a common source of refrigerant leaks that's often overlooked?

choices.b: Schrader valve cores on service ports

explanation.short: Schrader valve cores in service ports are common leak points often missed during leak detection.
explanation.detailed: Schrader valve leaks: service port valve cores can leak slowly; core can be damaged by improper tool use; caps should always be installed (secondary seal); leaks may be intermittent under pressure changes. Checking Schraders: use cap with gasket; soap test the core with system pressurized; replace cores if questionable; check that core is fully tightened. Always replace caps with good gaskets.

questions.question: How should an electronic leak detector be used effectively?

choices.b: Move probe slowly (1 inch per second) near potential leak points

explanation.short: Move the detector probe slowly (about 1 inch per second) around joints, connections, and potential leak points.
explanation.detailed: Electronic detector technique: start at highest points (refrigerant sinks); move probe 1 inch per second or slower; maintain 1/4 inch from surface; check all joints, fittings, valves, coils; in windy conditions, shield the area; when alarm sounds, back off and reapproach to pinpoint. Detector types: heated diode, corona discharge, infrared. Match detector to refrigerant type. Calibrate per manufacturer instructions.

questions.question: What is the advantage of UV dye leak detection?

choices.b: Pinpoints exact leak location where dye escapes and fluoresces under UV light
choices.d: Works with all refrigerant types equally

explanation.short: UV dye travels with the refrigerant and accumulates at leak points, fluorescing under UV light to pinpoint exact locations.
explanation.detailed: UV dye leak detection: dye added to system circulates with refrigerant; escapes at leak points; fluoresces bright yellow/green under UV light; excellent for finding exact leak location; can find very small leaks over time. Limitations: system must run for dye circulation; may not be compatible with all systems; takes time for dye to appear at leak. Good for intermittent or hard-to-find leaks.

questions.question: How does ultrasonic leak detection work?

choices.b: Detects high-frequency sound of gas escaping through a leak

explanation.short: Ultrasonic detectors hear the high-frequency sound produced when gas escapes through small openings.
explanation.detailed: Ultrasonic leak detection: gas escaping through small opening creates turbulence; turbulence produces ultrasonic sound (above human hearing); detector converts to audible sound or display. Advantages: works with any gas (including nitrogen); finds pressurized leaks; works in noisy environments (adjustable frequency). Limitations: requires some pressure differential; background ultrasonic noise can interfere. Useful for large systems and with nitrogen pressurization.

questions.question: What happens to compressor oil during refrigerant recovery?

choices.b: Some oil is removed with refrigerant and collects in recovery equipment

explanation.short: Some compressor oil travels with refrigerant during recovery and collects in the recovery machine's oil separator or cylinder.
explanation.detailed: Oil in recovery process: refrigerant carries some oil during recovery; oil collects in recovery machine's separator or cylinder; must be drained periodically; contaminated oil should be disposed properly; measure oil removed to replace equivalent amount in system. Recovery equipment with oil separators: trap oil before it enters cylinder; improve refrigerant purity; require regular draining.

questions.question: What is a typical test pressure for leak testing a refrigeration system?

choices.b: System design pressure or manufacturer's specified test pressure

explanation.short: Use the system's rated design pressure or manufacturer's specified test pressure - don't exceed system ratings.
explanation.detailed: Pressure test guidelines: use nitrogen (never oxygen); don't exceed system design pressure; typical residential: 150-400 psig depending on refrigerant; check nameplate or documentation for rating; use regulated nitrogen supply to control pressure; for new installations, hold test pressure for extended period (15-30 minutes minimum). Higher pressure = more sensitive test, but never exceed ratings.
